objdescid.compdate: 1812The final digit of the inscribed date is unclear; the date may be 1813.

objinfo.medium: relief etching (?)This work is probably a relief etching, although the technique for producing the stipple-like tones has never been determined. Blake may have used some form of aquatint to achieve this affect. The print may have been tinted with thin wash upper left.
objinfo.printingstyle: reliefIt appears as though both the relief lines and plateaus and the etched recesses have been lightly inked and printed.
objinfo.framelines: none on the printed leafThe single pen and ink framing line is on the mount, not on the leaf on which the etching is printed.
objinfo.binding: noneThe print is mounted in a window cut into a leaf of paper.
objinfo.stabholes: None on the print itself. There are stab holes along the left edge of the mount.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.
provenance.note: Probably inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; acquired by George A. Smith and bound by him in "about 1853" (Bentley page 337) with other works by Blake, including the manuscript "Order" of the *Songs of Innocence and of Experience*; the volume offered, presumably by Smith, at a Puttick and Simpson auction, London, 3-4 July 1863 (£15.15.s., possibly bought-in by Smith given the reappearance of the volume in the Smith auction of 1880); the volume offered by the dealer Bernard Quaritch, 1864 *Catalogue of Books*, item 6521, possibly on consignment from, or in partnership with, Smith (£21); the volume sold by Smith, Christie's, 1 April 1880, lot 168 (£66 to Quaritch); the volume apparently lent by Quaritch to William Muir, who used some works as the basis for his facsimiles; the volume offered by Quaritch, Oct. 1883 *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts*, item 10,252 (£80), May 1885 catalogue, *William Blake's Original Drawings*, page 2, no item number (£80), and 1887 *General Catalogue of Books*, volume 2, item 10,252 (£80); the volume acquired by Bernard Buchanan Macgeorge between 1892 and 1906; the volume sold from the Macgeorge collection, Sotheby's, 1 July 1924, lot 133 (£345 to the dealer E. Parsons & Sons); the volume, possibly with some leaves removed, offered by Maggs Bros., 1924 catalogue 456, item 53 (£630); the volume acquired no later than 1927 by George C. Smith who disbound the volume and rebound this print with three others by Blake, *Albion rose* Copy 2D, *The Accusers of Theft Adultery Murder* Copy 3G, and *The Man Sweeping the Interpreter's Parlour* Copy 2K; the volume of four prints sold from George C. Smith's collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 42 ($450 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); disbound and given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., in 1943.

desc.objtitle: The Chaining of Orc, Object 1 (Essick XVII)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this print, two figures stand above a supine figure against what may be a background of flames. Lying supine with his head at left near the lower edge of the composition, a nude male figure bends his head back and opens his mouth widely. He may look up toward the standing figures above. He has short hair and an area of flames(?) may encircle his head. Both arms are extended outward from his body with his left arm at 45 degrees and his right arm at 135 degrees. Shackles are visible around both wrists and appear to link the figure to the ground below. His torso is twisted slightly forward. His legs are together and shackles are also visible around both ankles. This figure is Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained. The ground below the figure may be a rock or earth covered in flame-like forms, perhaps grass or other vegetation. Above Orc, a female and a male figure stand facing forward on what may be a rock or higher ground. At left, the nude female figure bends forward and left with legs spread and grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. She has long curly hair and a circle, perhaps a halo, is visible around her head. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother. At right, the nude male figure stands with legs spread in a contrapposto position. He leans slightly to the left and turns his head to look left and down, perhaps toward the female figure and/or the figure lying below. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is short and his mouth may be open, and he may be speaking or crying out in despair. Like the female figure beside him, a circle that suggests a halo is visible around his head; spiky lines that may indicate beams of light extend outward from his halo. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, the couple has been identified as Adam and Eve, or as the "Dark virgin" and Urthona (another name for Los). To the right of the male figure's legs, a stone(?) is visible with Blake's signature and date. In the lower left corner of the composition, to the left of the supine figure's head, a structure with a domed roof is visible. A steeple topped with a cross stands in the middle of the dome, which suggests the structure in a church. This structure may suggest St. Paul's Cathedral in London. The majority of the background is indistinguishable, although an area of flames may be visible above the church at left. There may be clouds in the sky to the left of the standing male figure.

component.illusobjdesc: Lying supine with his head at left near the lower edge of the composition, a nude male figure bends his head back and opens his mouth widely. He may be speaking or crying out, and his expression suggests pain or terror. He may look up toward the standing figures above. He has short hair and an area of flames(?) may encircle his head. Both arms are extended outward from his body with his left arm at 45 degrees and his right arm at 135 degrees. Shackles are visible around both wrists and appear to link the figure to the ground below. His left palm is clearly turned down. His torso is twisted slightly forward. His legs are together and shackles are also visible around both ankles. This figure is Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained.
The ground below the supine figure Orc may be a stone or earth covered in fire or flame-like forms, perhaps grass or other vegetation.
The ground below the supine figure Orc may be a stone or earth covered in fire or flame-like forms, perhaps grass or other vegetation.

Above Orc, a female and a male figure stand facing forward on what may be a rock or higher ground. At left, the nude female figure bends forward and left with legs spread and grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. She may be crying. She has long curly hair and a circle, perhaps a halo, is visible around her head. Her legs are bent and her right foot is lifted slightly. Her genitals are prominent. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother. Alternatively, she has been identified as Eve, or as the "Dark virgin."

Above Orc, a female and a male figure stand facing forward on what may be a rock or higher ground. At right, the nude male figure stands with legs spread in a contrapposto position. He leans slightly to the left and turns his head to look left and down, perhaps toward the female figure and/or the figure lying below. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is short and his mouth may be open, and he may be speaking or crying out in despair. His genitals are prominent. Like the female figure beside him, a circle that suggests a halo is visible around his head; spiky lines that may indicate beams of light extend outward from his halo. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, he has been identified as Adam, or as Urthona (another name for Los).
To the right of the male figure's legs, a stone(?) is visible with Blake's signature and date.

In the lower left corner of the composition, to the left of the supine figure's head, a structure with a domed roof is visible. A steeple topped with a cross stands in the middle of the dome, which suggests the structure in a church. This structure may suggest St. Paul's Cathedral in London.
The majority of the background is indistinguishable, although an area of flames may be visible above the church at left. There may be clouds in the sky to the left of the standing male figure.

lg.l: 1812The final digit of the inscribed date is obscured by the background; the date may be 1813.
